item.title: /XMR/ Monero General — 249 replies
item.content:encoded:
/XMR/ Monero General

Open thread • Replies: 249 • Updated: 2026-02-15 18:02 UTC

OP

Welcome to /XMR/ Monero General, dedicated to the discussion of the world's most widely adopted privacy coin.

XMR payments are anonymous, low-fee, and fully fungible. Users can send and receive XMR globally without having to worry about tainted coins. Battle-tested privacy tech (Ring Signatures, Stealth Addresses and RingCT) ensures that critical TX data cannot be gleaned from the Monero blockchain; the TX history of all XMR users is kept hidden, with TXs being optionally transparent via the aid of a view key.

XMR ensures low TX fees by employing a dynamic block size that can "stretch" to easily accommodate sudden TX spikes.

XMR's mining algorithm, RandomX, is optimized for devices using general-purpose CPUs e.g. desktops, laptops, smartphones, tablets, keeping the barrier to entry low and ASICs out of the equation.

XMR's tail emission - 0.6 XMR per block forever - incentivizes for-profit miners to keep mining, helping boost long-term network security. This constant linear inflation trends to zero and is offset by coin loss.

XMR has proven to be the only altcoin capable of overcoming BTC's network effect by driving it out of the darknet economy BTC dominated for over 10 years. XMR is also starting to overtake BTC in clearnet commerce as well.

If you still have questions, feel free to ask. A MoneroChad will be with you shortly.

From: Clay Dunnagan
Sent: Wednesday, August 31, 2011 10:39 PM
Subject: The Silver Screw

THE SILVER SCREW

Once upon a time, a young lad was born without a belly button. In its place was a silver screw. All the doctors told his mother that there was nothing they could do.

Like it or not, he was stuck with it . . . He was screwed.

All the years of growing up were real tough on him, as all who saw the screw made fun of him. He avoided leaving his house . . . And thus, never made any friends.

One day, a mysterious stranger saw his belly and told him of a monk in Tibet who could get rid of the screw for him. He was thrilled. The next day, he took all of his life's savings and bought a ticket to Nepal .

After several days of climbing up steep cliffs, he came upon a giant monastery. The monk knew exactly why he had come. The screwy guy was told to sleep in the highest tower of the monastery and the following day when he awoke, the screw would have been removed. The man immediately went to the room and fell asleep.

During the night while he slept, a purple fog floated in an open window. In the mist floated a solid silver screwdriver. In just moments, the screwdriver removed the screw and disappeared out the window.

The next morning when the man awoke, he saw the silver screw laying on the pillow next to him. Reaching down, he felt his navel, and there was no screw there! Jubilant, he leaped out of bed . . . And his ass fell off.

The moral to this is:

'Don't screw around with things you don't understand -- You could lose your ass.'

Sent from my iPhone

>>61851319
The are long term, short term, and medium term markets.

Short term would be ones that only last about a hour, such as “Will the price of Bitcoin be 66,500 or greater by 2pm?” Every one of those markets are actually broken down into 1,000 or 500 increments and you can gamble in each one. “Will BC be over 58,000 by 2pm?” That bet will have a very small returnif you buy Yes, and it resolves as Yes, because everyone will be betting Yes as well (because it’s very likely t to hat the price will be over 58k). Will it be over 69,750? Well, the price for those contracts can change drastically over the hour, as Bitcoin rises and falls in real time, hovering around that point, dipping above and below it.

Another short term bet are the mentions markets like in the OP. Some don’t open until the day of the event. But some are two or three days before. Sportsball games are often medium term as well, with prices changing in the lead up and during the games.

There’s a week long “what will trump say this week” market that resets every Monday morning. Those can be lucrative if you can get in early (around 10am eastern time on Monday), buy the right positions, and have a little luck. For instance a No position on a term he hasn’t been using lately might be cheap at the start of the week but much more expensive as the week goes on. But you have to get in early, almost like an IPO.

There are long term options that won’t resolve for weeks or months the, but they see very little movement unless the news changes. Who will be the Dem president rial nominee? Well, even if you’re right you won’t see a resolution until the DNC announces who it is in 2028.

You could also stick with small bets on sportsball. It can be pretty safe if you pick 75%+ odds, and pay attention to the game so far if you’re betting on live action.
